essay.question-text: Using points and examples from the talk, explain the theory about the unusual orbit of one of the planets.
essay.sample-answer-text:
SAMPLE ANSWER
In this lecture, the professor discusses the orbits of the planets, with an emphasis on the unusual orbit of the planet Pluto.
The eight inner planets have circular orbits, but Pluto's orbit is elliptical, or long and narrow. Pluto's orbit is usually outside Neptune's, but because Pluto's orbit is elliptical, it is inside Neptune's orbit occasionally, every 248 years.
The theory about why Pluto's orbit is so unusual is that Pluto may not be a planet. Perhaps Pluto used to be one of Neptune's moons and used to be in orbit around Neptune. Then it broke out of Neptune's orbit and is now in an irregular orbit around the Sun.
